item.description:
Garden City planted the seeds of victory a long time ago.

The impenetrable Trojans football team defeated Baldwin 31-0 in the quarterfinals, setting a New York state record with 63 consecutive wins, which dates back to 2020, after falling to Lindenhurst in the Long Island title game the year prior.

‚ÄúTo be at the top of New York State is something that the program deserves,‚Äù head coach Dave Ettinger, who has won the last nine Nassau County titles and five Long Island championships, told The Post.

‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt talk about [the streak] a lot, but we have spoken about it the last couple of weeks because I do think it‚Äôs important for the program to achieve that.‚Äù

Attention now shifts to winning game No. 64, a semifinal match against East Meadow, for reasons beyond simply maintaining the milestone.

‚ÄúOur plan has always been one week at a time, so I don‚Äôt think that they‚Äôve gotten ahead of themselves,‚Äù the coach said of winning Nassau title No. 10.

‚ÄúWe need a clean, focused game‚Ä¶ trying to make them do some different things to beat us and executing on offense.‚Äù

The Trojans‚Äô maturity is also something of a wonder as the bunch gets down to work each day without much typical high school sophomoric behavior or even team rituals.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre pretty boring,‚Äù joked Ettinger. ‚ÄúWe kind of just stick to the plan and try to put a good plan in each week.‚Äù

In football, Long Beach (7-2), a three seed, takes on No. 2 seed Mepham (7-1) in semifinal play at 10:30 a.m. Sunday at Hofstra University, and will play the winner of Garden City vs. East Meadow in the conference II finals.

Undefeated Massapequa (9-0), a one seed, plays No. 5 Syosset (5-4) in the conference I semifinals at Hofstra at 4 p.m. Friday.
item.author: Alex Mitchell

item.title: Ê≥¢ÁâπÂÖ∞ÁöÑÁ§æ‰ºö‰∏ª‰πâÁÅæÈöæÂ∫îËØ•‰∏∫Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ÈÄâÊ∞ëZohran MamdaniÊï≤ÂìçË≠¶Èíü
item.description:
If the travails of a certain Left Coast city are any guide, Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs plan to paint New York red is not only bound to fail but also to alienate voters once they get a real taste of his socialist ‚Äúutopia.‚Äù

The mayor-elect wants to hand out everything from frozen rents and free buses to subsidized trans surgeries even for kids. He wants the so-called 1% of wealthy New Yorkers who already pay for most of the freebies to pay even more to foot the bill.

That message won him the mayoralty, but what he left out of his pitch is what happens next. Just how much do people really like progressive government, and what happens to local economies and standards of living when lefty pols go there?

Take Oregon. The state is one of the most progressive in the country, providing a suite of social welfare benefits courtesy of super high taxes on business and a state income tax. It has in recent years embraced various methods to defund and defang the police ‚Äì all stuff supported by our new mayor.

Its largest city, Portland, has embraced various forms of socialism, the same stuff spouted by our mayor elect. It also has become a poster child of urban decay, a smoldering mess of crime, businesses fleeing and homeless. People have had enough.

According to the survey conducted by Public Opinion Strategies (financed by the a pro-business advocacy group ‚ÄúSave our Cities‚Äù) here are the results:

  • ‚ÄØ67% say Oregon‚Äôs economy is ‚Äúpretty seriously off on the wrong track‚Äù because of mountainous taxes, regulations and homelessness.
  • Independents are the largest voting block and 73% believe the state is on the wrong track.
  • Portland, of course, has been one of the epicenters of social justice since 2020. Massive protests and various government programs to provide equity. But people in the state say they now care more about jobs and the economy over this lefty fad by a margin of 62% to 15%.

The numbers don‚Äôt lie. Oregon was once a burgeoning tech hub but big employers like Intel have been cutting staff. Its unemployment rate is growing to 5%, the highest since COVID. The Wall Street Journal recently reported about the difficulty in leasing space in downtown Portland: the US Bancorp Tower, ‚Äúonce a premier address in the city, was afflicted with ‚Äòvagrants sleeping in hallways of vacant office floors.‚Äô ‚Äú

As the Journal reported, the vagrants were ‚Äústarting fires in stairwells, smoking fentanyl and defecating in common areas,‚Äù citing a so-called lease-termination lawsuit by a former tenant.

The building, with a 60% vacancy rate, was recently sold for $45 million. In 2015, it had fetched nearly $400 million.

Yes Oregonians (like New Yorkers) put the lefties in power, but now after living with all of the above, there is growing evidence that they‚Äôve had enough.

It should provide a stark warning to the ruling Democratic Party: Go all in on socialism by supporting the extreme policies of Mamdani, and you will likely face a continued exodus from your states ‚Äì and a revolt from those voters who stick around.
item.author: Charles Gasparino

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÆæËÆ°Â∏àÁéõËéé¬∑ËØ∫ÂÖ∞Ôºà Martha Nolan ÔºâÁöÑÊúãÂèã‰ª¨ÂºÄÁé©Á¨ëËØ¥ÔºåÂú®Â•πË¢´ÂèëÁé∞Ê≠ªÂú®ËíôÊâòÂÖãËàπ‰∏ä‰πãÂâçÔºåÂ•πÂú®‰ª§‰∫∫Èöæ‰ª•ÂøòÊÄÄÁöÑÁü≠‰ø°‰∏≠Ë∞àÂà∞‰∫ÜÂ•πÁöÑÊ≠ª‰∫°„ÄÇ
item.description:
Friends of the Manhattan fashion designer found dead at the Montauk Yacht Club sent her a haunting text message joking that ‚Äúmaybe she‚Äôs dead‚Äù hours before her body was discovered.

Martha Nolan-O‚ÄôSlatarra, 33, was at the swanky yacht club on Long Island‚Äôs South Fork for a meeting with investor and boat owner Christopher Durnan to discuss the expansion of her swimwear fashion company East x East on August 4.

‚ÄúIf you guys are looking for more money, let‚Äôs sit down and talk about it,‚Äù Durnan wrote in a text to Nolan-O‚ÄôSlatarra and her business partner Dylan Grace,¬†according to New York Magazine.

The 33-year-old, who went by Martha Nolan professionally, was scheduled to meet with Durnan ‚Äî¬†who owns a 13 percent stake in the brand ‚Äî at 4 p.m., but was pushed back three hours.

Nolan and Durnan took a boat ride on one of his two vessels to watch the sunset and drink champagne while Grace skipped the meeting due to an overseas trip to Greece, according to the outlet.

During their trip out to sea, the fashion designer‚Äôs friends and boyfriend, Nicholas DiRubio, became concerned when she wasn‚Äôt answering any messages sent to her.

The panicked pals tracked Nolan‚Äôs location to somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean before listing possible reasons for her radio silence.

‚Äúlmao. I‚Äôm sure her phone died. Or maybe she‚Äôs dead,‚Äù read one message sent at 9:20 p.m.

Ten minutes later, Nolan confirmed that she was back at the yacht club.

‚ÄúLol I‚Äôm at the yacht club now, my phone is on,‚Äù she wrote to the group.

Nolan is believed to have died about an hour after sending the message, according to police. She was found unconscious on the docked vessel ‚ÄúRipple‚Äù after residents nearby reported hearing screams late at night.

Durnan was found running around the yacht club naked, throwing sunscreen at other boats, attempting to get their attention.

‚ÄúI think for me it‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòWhy is the man naked, right?'‚Äù one unidentified friend told the outlet.

Nolan was pronounced dead at the scene.

Officials found no signs of violence on her body, deepening the mystery of the grim discovery.

An official cause of death has not been released. Investigators suspect she died from an accidental overdose influenced by ‚Äúdesigner drugs,‚Äù after a powdery white substance was found near her body on the moored vessel.

Cops still don‚Äôt definitively know if the powder discovered near¬†the 33-year-old beauty¬†is heroin, cocaine, fentanyl, or a deadly cocktail of all three.

Police had been searching for the dealers in the area who may have sold the drugs believed to have killed Nolan.

‚Äú[These dealers] may or may not have known [they were selling] poison to this girl, but that doesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù a source told The Post in August.

‚ÄúWith higher profile cases like this poor girl in Montauk, you‚Äôre going to see more and more of these dealers getting locked up,‚Äù the source said.

Prosecutors could ‚Äúseek manslaughter or [criminally negligent] homicide charges‚Äù against the drug peddlers, the same source said. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a slew of possession and trafficking charges, and they could decide to get [federal authorities] involved, which would mean more time in prison if these bastards are convicted.‚Äù
item.author: Nicholas McEntyre

item.title: ‰πòÂÆ¢ÊøÄÂ¢ûÂêéÔºåÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÊ∏°ËΩÆËà™Á∫øÂ∞Ü‰∫é12ÊúàÈáçÊñ∞ËÆæËÆ°
item.description:
Ferry big changes are coming.

NYC Ferry routes will be operating with major changes starting Dec. 8 ‚Äî including combined routes with new stops ‚Äî as part of an new ‚Äúoptimized‚Äù ferry plan designed to carry more New Yorkers between boroughs.

Under the new Ferry Optimization Plan, riders will finally be able to trek from Brooklyn and Staten Island via the St. George route, which starts in West Manhattan and ends at Wall Street.

The expanded route will also provide access from Brooklyn to Manhattan‚Äôs west side via ferry for the first time, according to the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the nonprofit that manages the fleet.

The upcoming changes mark ‚Äúthe first-ever systemwide redesign to deliver faster commutes, better connections, and improved service for New Yorkers across all five boroughs,‚Äù NYCEDC President & CEO Andrew Kimball said in a statement.

Another new route ‚Äî a combined Soundview and Rockaway service ‚Äî will shuttle commuters from Throgs Neck in the Bronx to Manhattan‚Äôs east side and then all the way to the Rockaways in Queens.

The combination will fill previously near-empty boats going toward the Bronx during morning rides, the agency said.

East River service will also be split in two routes at most times of day under the new plan due to allow for more seat availability, ‚Äúincreasing capacity and making trips faster,‚Äù according to the agency.

Both routes will start at at East 34th Street, with Route A stopping at Hunters Point South and North Williamsburg and Route B stopping at Greenpoint and South Williamsburg.

A pilot service will kickoff in South Brooklyn on summer weekends in 2026, extending the new South Brooklyn route to Bay Ridge and Sunset Park.

The results of the pilot will be analyzed the following fall.

The news comes as the ferry system saw ridership numbers explode in recent years. Ridership in the first quarter of 2025 soared nearly 6% year-over-year and a whopping 35% since 2019.

The surge notably comes after Manhattan congestion tolling charges were implemented in January of this year. The controversial tolling program in Manhattan has even pushed some Bronx residents to advocate for their own ferry service, The Post previously reported.

The water-based expansion also appears to show no signs of slowing down, as a new report from the agency released Monday outlines plans for two new stops at East Harlem‚Äôs 125th Street and the MADE-Bush Terminal in Sunset Park, as well as upgrades to East 34th Street ‚Äî one of the system‚Äôs busiest terminals.

The report also floated potential sites in Canarsie, East Midtown, Coney Island and Far Rockaway, as well as JFK and LaGuardia airports.

The EDC noted it will begin to develop a plan for the next phases of NYC Ferry service in early 2026 with input from the public and officials to ensure the updated routes can ‚Äúaddress community needs and reflect changing priorities around the city.‚Äù
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal

item.title: ÂüÉËéâÊñØ¬∑ÊñØÁâπÂá°Â∞ºÂÖãÔºà Elise Stefanik ÔºâÂú®Â∑ûÈïøÁöÑÁ´ûÈÄâÂπøÂëä‰∏≠‚ÄúËÑ±ËäÇ‚ÄùÂíå‚Äú‰∏çÂèóÊ¨¢Ëøé‚ÄùÁöÑÂáØË•ø¬∑Èúç‰∏òÂ∞îÔºà Kathy Hochul Ôºâ Ôºö ‚ÄúËøôÂè™ÂÖ¨ÁâõÂøÖÈ°ªÂÅúÊ≠¢‚Äù
item.description:
Republican gubernatorial candidate Elise Stefanik ripped Kathy Hochul in a blistering new ad Friday that was essentially a montage of the Democratic incumbent‚Äôs lowlights as New York governor.¬†

The minute-long spot, titled ‚ÄúKathy‚Äôs Own Words: This Bulls‚Äìt Has to Stop,‚Äù is the second statewide digital ad released by the upstate congresswoman since the launch of her New York gubernatorial campaign.

The ad begins with an image of Hochul and newscasters repeating the phrase, ‚ÄúWorst governor in America‚Äù ‚Äì which is how Stefanik referred to the incumbent when she launched her campaign last week.¬†

‚ÄúHochul is out of touch,‚Äù the narrator says, before brutal clips of Hochul‚Äôs missteps as governor play ‚Äì including her May 2024 assertion that black children ‚Äúgrowing up in the Bronx‚Äù don‚Äôt know what the word ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù means.

Footage of hecklers taunting Hochul last month with ‚ÄúTax the Rich‚Äù chants at New York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs rally with Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D-NY) and Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), as well as the governor‚Äôs, ‚ÄúI can hear you‚Äù response is also shown.¬†

‚ÄúUnpopular,‚Äù the narrator continues, as a clip of the Empire State gov. getting viciously booed in September at the Ryder Cup golf tournament on Long Island is played.¬†

‚ÄúNot for us,‚Äù the voiceover states, ahead of a clip of Stefanik hammering Hochul in an interview for making New York ‚Äúthe most unaffordable state in the nation.‚Äù¬†

Stefanik then uses the governor‚Äôs own words against her, with a clip of Hochul telling reporters: ‚ÄúThis bulls‚Äìt has to stop.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to save New York,‚Äù the ad concludes. ‚ÄúElise for governor.‚Äù¬†

In a statement, Stefanik said the ‚Äúbulls‚Äìt‚Äù will stop when voters head to the polls next November.¬†

‚ÄúKathy Hochul has earned the title of Worst Governor in America because she has made New York the most unaffordable state in the nation,‚Äù the congresswoman said. ‚ÄúThese are your words Kathy: ‚ÄòThis bulls‚Äìt has to stop.‚Äô

‚ÄúAnd it will when Republicans, Democrats, and Independents unify next November to fire Kathy Hochul and save New York with common-sense policies that make our state affordable and safe.‚Äù

A poll released earlier this week found Stefanik nearly neck-and-neck with the governor.

Hochul was backed by 46% of voters to 43% for Stefanik, which was within the margin of error, according to the survey conducted by J.L. Partners.
item.author: Victor Nava

item.title: Â∏ñÂ≠êËÆ∞ËÄÖÂú®Êù∞ÂÖã¬∑ÊñΩÊ¥õÊñØ‰ºØÊ†ºÔºà Jack Schlossberg ÔºâËàíÈÄÇÁöÑÁîüÊ¥ª‰∏≠Â∫¶Ëøá‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂ§©‚Äî‰ªñÊòØÊîøÊ≤ªÁïåÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑÔºàÂíåÂ∑•‰ΩúÂÆ≥ÁæûÁöÑÔºâ‰æÑÂ≠ê
item.description:
Call me a Jack of all trades.

Or perhaps no trades.

I was the envy of the office when my editor asked me to spend a day living like Jack Schlossberg, the occasionally employed political scion most famous for feuding with family members, celebrities and strangers on social media.

‚ÄúSome reporters get dispatched to war,‚Äù one colleague tartly remarked. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll get to kick back, relax and do nothing.‚Äù

Since graduating from Harvard Law School in 2022, there‚Äôs been the assumption that the 32-year-old Park Avenue-raised grandson of John F. Kennedy has been living life on easy street.

Unburdened by pesky student loans (Harvard Law tuition costs a cool $80,000 a year), Schlossberg has been free to spend his time paddleboarding, posting to TikTok, and working at a surf shop in Hawaii.

So, news this week that he‚Äôs making a run for Rep. Jerry Nadler‚Äôs soon-to-be vacated seat in New York‚Äôs 12th Congressional District has raised eyebrows, given his r√©sum√© is as slender as his 6-foot-2 frame.

But the self-described ‚Äúsilly goose‚Äù is a serious contender.

As Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs mayoral victory proved, experience counts less than charisma ‚Äî and Schlossberg has it in spades.

His hundreds of thousands of social media followers fawn as he saunters around the city, singing, cycling, and imitating various public figures.

My editor asked if I was up for the challenge of living like Jack. After all, what‚Äôs more Jack Schlossberg than poking gentle fun at someone in the spotlight? As they say, imitation is the sincerest form of flattery.

To be clear, we don‚Äôt have much in common: He‚Äôs a little younger, his hair is a lot thicker ‚Äî and there‚Äôs also the matter of his multi-million-dollar trust fund.

But there are some similarities: namely, our need for attention and the enjoyment we both clearly get from seeing our pictures in the paper.

Taking voters for a ride?

Schlossberg doesn‚Äôt shy away from his impressive lineage, even as Democrats rally against nepotism and ‚Äúwhite privilege.‚Äù

The same people who attend ‚ÄúNo Kings‚Äù rallies have cheekily crowned Schlossberg ‚Äúthe people‚Äôs princess.‚Äù

Like his forebears, the savvy scion is utilizing modern media to help craft his image ‚Äî one that‚Äôs equal parts corny, cool and ironic ‚Äî but some say he‚Äôs riffing a little too hard.

Campaign photos that show Schlossberg cycling through the city are an obvious ode to paparazzi pictures of his late uncle, John F. Kennedy, Jr.

It‚Äôs prompted critics to wonder whether Schlossberg is simply taking voters for a ride ‚Äî literally and figuratively. Is this entire campaign just a vanity project? Something to keep the Camelot mythmaking machine alive?

Time will tell how it all pans out, but Schlossberg seamlessly weaves in and out of Manhattan traffic while carrying both flowers and a skateboard.

My attempt: a little less graceful.

He memes business

While many might dismiss Schlossberg‚Äôs incessant TikTok and Instagram use as a folly, he‚Äôs meeting millennial and Gen Z voters where they are.

To his credit, it‚Äôs hard to break through on social media ‚Äî and the Harvard grad is a master meme-maker.

And if he‚Äôs not working a job, he‚Äôs certainly working his angles.

Schlossberg can perfectly pose for selfies and shirtless snaps, like the one below. (Disclaimer: I refused to take my shirt off for this assignment, and your eyes will thank me for that.)

Schlossberg boasts nearly a million followers on TikTok and Instagram each ‚Äî and he needs the edge.

The race to represent the 12th Congressional District is already shaping up to be uber-competitive, and Schlossberg can‚Äôt rely on his good looks to get him over the line.

The primary is already set to be packed with young, dreamy Democrats.

Alex Bores, the 35-year-old Cornell-educated hunk who currently serves in the New York State Assembly, has already thrown his hat in the ring.

Yale grad and Rhodes Scholar Liam Elkind is also a contender, as is Cameron Kasky, a 24-year-old survivor of the Parkland school shooting.

Instagram account @thatgaygucandlecompany quipped: ‚ÄúIs New York‚Äôs 12th congressional district about to experience the hottest primary ever?‚Äù

Take time to smell the flowers

Schlossberg announced his Congressional bid in a 4,500-word New York Times piece that was heavy on the details of his social media spats, but curiously light on talk about politics and policy.

Is Schlossberg, who endorsed Zohran Mamdani, a Park Avenue populist? What does he think of the price of groceries? And what would he say to critics who accuse him of never having held down meaningful employment in the district he aims to represent?

It‚Äôs all unclear ‚Äî but the piece did note that he loves to keep flowers in his ‚Äúmodest‚Äù one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea (rents for similar lodgings list for upwards of $5,000 a month on Zillow).

The Times piece was accompanied by pictures of the aspiring politician popping into a florist to pick up some flowers, so obviously I had to follow suit.

Schlossberg‚Äôs lack of policy proposals has already alarmed some, including the progressive political account Notice News.

The millionaire has mentioned a ‚Äúcost of living crisis,‚Äù but it remains to be seen whether he can really connect with cash-strapped millennials and zoomers who are increasingly anxious about their financial futures.

Navigating choppy waters

Schlossberg is an avid stand-up paddleboarder, often seen traversing the Hudson River, so a real day in the life wouldn‚Äôt be complete if I didn‚Äôt follow suit.

Sadly, however, I wasn‚Äôt up to the task.

A recent night kayak on the Hudson had me terrified ‚Äî and I arrived back on dry land in tears.

Jack is clearly braver than I ‚Äî and running for public office is no small feat.

Who knows how he‚Äôll fare, but when you‚Äôre Jack Schlossberg, the wind is always at your back.
item.author: Andrew Court

item.title: Luigi MangioneÂæãÂ∏àÁàÜÁÇ∏Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄÊ£ÄÂØüÂÆòÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Áº∫‰πèËØÅÊçÆË°®ÊòéÂ¶àÂ¶àÂëäËØâË≠¶ÂØüÔºåÂ•πÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÁúãÂà∞Â•πÁöÑÂÑøÂ≠êÂ∞ÑÂáªÂåªÁñó‰øùÂÅ•È¶ñÂ∏≠ÊâßË°åÂÆò
item.description:
Attorneys for Luigi Mangione accused the Manhattan DA and the NYPD‚Äôs chief of detectives¬†of not offering evidence of his mother‚Äôs alleged statement that killing United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson was something¬†she could see her son do, according to court documents.

During a December 2024 news conference, Chief of Detectives Joseph Kenny referenced information the FBI received from San Francisco police, according to the court filing made public Tuesday.

A police sergeant had reached out to the FBI after believing the murder suspect caught in pictures released by the NYPD bore a resemblance to Mangione, the filing recalled.

Kenny spoke of an alleged conversation between Mangione‚Äôs mother and San Francisco police, where she reportedly suggested that she could see her son gunning down the Thompson, the document said.

‚ÄúThey had a conversation where she didn‚Äôt indicate that it was her son in the photograph, but she said it might be something that she could see him doing,‚Äù Kenny told reporters, according to the document.

Mangione‚Äôs mother had filed a missing persons report for her son on Nov. 18, 2024.

The accused killer‚Äôs defense attorneys now claim that prosecutors have provided no evidence that Mangione‚Äôs mother made such comments.

‚ÄúTo date, there has been no documentation provided in discovery that confirms the Chief of Detectives‚Äô statement as to Mrs. Mangione‚Äôs alleged statement,‚Äù defense attorney Karen Friedman Agnifilo wrote in a filing Tuesday.

‚ÄúIn fact, all the discovery provided so far indicates that she did not make such a statement,‚Äù Agnifilo wrote.

‚ÄúIf it is true that Mrs. Mangione never made this statement, then it is shocking and unconscionable that the District Attorney‚Äôs Office and the NYPD have never corrected this highly prejudicial false statement,‚Äù she maintained.

The filing referenced several media reports that published his mother‚Äôs statement, including the recently published novel ‚ÄúLuigi: The Making and The Meaning,‚Äù by John H Richardson.

‚ÄúThe Chief of Detectives‚Äô unfounded claims continue to be cited, as it was recently repeated in a reckless novel that was published on November 4, 2025,‚Äù Agnifilo wrote.

Mangione‚Äôs team of defense attorneys implored the judge to declare the Manhattan DA‚Äôs office certification of compliance with information regarding Mangione‚Äôs mother as insufficient, the filing said.

Prosecutors are expected to respond in a future filing.

Mangione, 27, has pleaded not guilty to federal and state charges of murdering Thompson outside a hotel hosting the insurance giant‚Äôs annual investor conference in Midtown Manhattan.

The Ivy League grad was arrested in Altoona, Pa., after a five-day manhunt.

The federal government¬†says it is seeking the death penalty in its own case.

Mangione is due back in court for the federal case on Dec. 5.
item.author: Zoe Hussain

item.title: ÊØÅÁÅ≠ÊÄßÁöÑÁÅ´ÁÑ∞Á©øËøáÂéÜÂè≤ÊÇ†‰πÖÁöÑÈïøÂ≤õÂÜúÂú∫ÔºåÊùÄÊ≠ªÊï∞ÂçÅÂè™Âä®Áâ©Ôºå‰º§ÂÆ≥‰∫ÜËØïÂõæÊãØÊïëÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂÆ∂‰∫∫
item.description:
A massive fire tore through a historic Long Island family farm, destroying its main barn and injuring those who raced inside to save the animals, according to police.¬†

Dozens of animals were killed in the devastating fire at the family-owned Wells Farm in Northville, prompting a massive response from half a dozen fire departments and the Riverhead Police Department Wednesday evening.

Laura Wells, whose husband and son run the day-to-day operations of the East End farm, said the family is shattered and unsure how they‚Äôll recover after watching the barn ‚Äî an old, sprawling wooden structure ‚Äî go up in flames within minutes.

‚ÄúThis is just devastating,‚Äù she told News 12 Long Island.¬†

‚ÄúI honestly don‚Äôt know what we‚Äôre going to do.‚Äù

Wells said that first responders and relatives sprinted into the burning building to pull out as many trapped animals as possible, saving 19 pigs, but two others perished alongside dozens of chickens before anyone could reach them.

‚ÄúMy two granddaughters ended up in the hospital trying to rescue the pigs,‚Äù Wells said.¬†

‚ÄúThank goodness for the police and the firefighters. They helped us get the pigs out of there.‚Äù

One cop and both granddaughters were treated for smoke inhalation at the scene and taken to Peconic Bay Medical Center, police said.

Animal advocacy group, Humane Long Island, was called to the property to inspect the animals, many of which suffered burns, lacerations and heavy smoke exposure, they said.¬†

A cause for the fire hasn‚Äôt been determined yet, but police said it does not appear to be a case of arson.
item.author: Brandon Cruz

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÂΩìÈÄâ‰∫∫‰ΩêÂÖ∞¬∑È©¨ÂßÜËææÂ∞ºÔºà Zohran Mamdani Ôºâ‰∏æË°å‰∫ÜÁßòÂØÜÁöÑ‰ºä‰∏ΩËééÁôΩ¬∑Ê≤É‰º¶Ôºà Elizabeth Warren Ôºâ‰ºöËÆÆÔºåÂ•πÂêπÊçß‰ªñÁöÑ‚ÄúÂêëÂØå‰∫∫ÂæÅÁ®é‚ÄùËÆÆÁ®ãÔºö ‚Äú‰∫ø‰∏áÂØåÁøÅÁöÑÁúº
item.description:
Zohran Mamdani held a secretive meeting with far-left Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren on Wednesday ‚Äî a sitdown that was captured by an eagle-eyed New Yorker whose office is across from the mayor-elect‚Äôs headquarters.

Warren boasted about the meeting with the Democratic socialist and¬†Big Tech antagonist Lina Khan, the co-chair of Mamdani‚Äôs transition team, on¬†Instagram.

‚ÄúTax the rich. Billionaire tears not pictured,‚Äù Warren captioned the post of the beaming trio.

The nosy neighbor who works in the building across the street from Mamdani snapped a picture of him and Warren ‚Äúin deep debate‚Äù on Nov. 12, according to a post on¬†X.

‚ÄúUpdate: the blinds are all closed this morning,‚Äù¬†he wrote Thursday.

Exact details of the trio‚Äôs meeting are unclear. The Post reached out to Mamdani and Warren for comment.

Warren is a¬†notorious hater of Wall Street¬†who gushed about Mamdani‚Äôs ‚Äústeely‚Äù focus on affordability over the summer, saying his fantastical promises of free child care, transit and rent freezes are the true ‚ÄúDemocratic message.‚Äù

Maria Danzilo, a former candidate for the New York state Senate, gawked at the Bay State progressive‚Äôs apparent ‚Äúobsession‚Äù with the incoming mayor.

‚ÄúThis woman will not rest until she brings down America, starting with NYC. It‚Äôs bad enough we have [AOC] here,‚Äù Danzilo seethed on¬†X.

‚ÄúNYC is bleeding jobs and it‚Äôs headed for anti-growth and a death spiral thanks to years of De Blasio, no course correction with Adams, and now four years of [t]his! She should go back to Massachusetts and leave NYC the heck alone.‚Äù

Others, growing fretful about the other lefty politicians swarming around Mamdani, couldn‚Äôt help but agree.

‚ÄúWelp Bernie said it. He wants to bring Mamdani politics all across the country,‚Äù one user wrote, referring to independent Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders,¬†who rallied with Mamdani just before the election.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think her policies work for nyc,‚Äù another person noted.

‚ÄúShe is a MA senator‚Ä¶why is she even there?‚Äù one user wondered.
item.author: Caitlin McCormack

item.title: ÊçÆÁß∞Âú®ÊõºÂìàÈ°øÁî®Êû™Â®ÅËÉÅÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶‰∫∫ÂêéÔºå‰∏ÄÂêçÁî∑Â≠êË¢´Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂºÄÊû™ÊâìÊ≠ªÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
Police shot and killed an allegedly armed man in a confrontation on the Upper East Side Thursday night, according to law enforcement sources and authorities.

Cops received a 911 call just after 7 p.m. about a man who was spotted waving a gun at people near East 107th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan, according to sources and the NYPD.

Less than 20 minutes later, cops discovered the reported gun-touting assailant a few blocks down by East 96th Street, police said.

The man, who matched the description provided by 911 callers, allegedly fired a round at the officers, according to sources.

The cops discharged their guns and returned fire, striking him once in the chest and once in the hip in a confrontation, according to sources and police.

The unidentified man was rushed to Mount Sinai Hospital in critical condition, authorities added.

He was later pronounced dead, sources said.

A firearm was recovered on the scene, according to police.

The investigation remains ongoing.
item.author: Joe Marino, Larry Celona, Zoe Hussain

item.title: 83Â≤ÅÁöÑLIÂ•∂Â•∂ÁöÑÊñ∞ËΩ¨ÊäòÔºåÂ•πÂ£∞Áß∞‰∏çÁü•ÈÅìÂ•π‰ºöÁ´ûÈÄâÈïáÁöÑÊúÄÈ´òËÅå‰ΩçÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÂØπÁ≠æÂêçË°®Á§∫ÊÄÄÁñë
item.description:
It‚Äôs turned into a political whodunit.

Questions continue to swirl around an 83-year-old Long Island grandmother whose mysterious presence on the Working Families Party line in the Huntington supervisor‚Äôs race tipped the scales in the election with the voters who signed her petition nowhere to be found.

Public records show that the town employee listed as a witness on the party petition for granny Maria Delgado hasn‚Äôt lived at his listed Greenlawn address for at least four years ‚Äî and the folks living there now told News12 Long Island they never signed it.

Meanwhile, the Huntington Manor fire commissioner, who also signed, has yet to turn up.

‚ÄúUnless the law requires the board to invalidate a petition, it is deemed valid and the candidates named are placed on the ballot,‚Äù Suffolk County Board of Election commissioners John Alberts and Erin McTiernan said in a joint statement.

Delgado‚Äôs presence on the ballot caused a stir in the race because the Working Families line managed to siphon enough liberal votes from Democrat challenger Cooper Macco to give incumbent GOP Supervisor Ed Smyth, who won the seat in a squeaker.

Delgado initially told Newsday that she had no clue she was on the ballot, but then clammed up ‚Äî while a man at her home this week implied she did know she was a candidate.

‚ÄúShe ran, she lost, and I‚Äôm proud of her,‚Äù the unidentified man said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre proud of her. No comment.‚Äù

Now everyone is ticked off ‚Äî except town Republicans.

‚ÄúThe truth is straightforward: members of the Working Families Party selected their own slate of candidates instead of the Democrats‚Äô preferred choices,‚Äù Huntington Town GOP Chairman Thomas McNally said in a scathing statement this week.

‚ÄúThe Democratic Party ran against them in June ‚Äî and they lost,‚Äù McNally said.

‚ÄúWhat we are seeing now is post-election spin and sour grapes.‚Äù

He said Delgado knew she was on the party‚Äôs ballot and voted in both the primary and general election.

However, the state Working Families Party isn‚Äôt too thrilled about the controversy.

‚ÄúRepublicans have tricked voters and hijacked the Working Families ballot line to skew the election results,‚Äù said Ana Maria Archilla and Jasmine Gripper, co-directors for the state‚Äôs Working Families Party.¬†

‚ÄúWhat happened in Huntington is proof that Republicans have little respect for our democracy and for working people who stand to lose so much with their disastrous policies.‚Äù

The Board of Elections, which ignored numerous requests for comment until The Post filed for access to the petitions, said that no objections were raised at the time Delgado‚Äôs petition was filed.

A spokesperson said there were only ‚Äúcurable‚Äù issues that were later fixed, and notified Delgado as required ‚Äî but has no legal authority to investigate beyond that.

However, state Attorney General Letitia James‚Äô office confirmed Wednesday that her office is reviewing the results of the elections but stopped short of calling it an investigation.
item.author: Brandon Cruz, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇËÆÆÂëòErik BottcherÂÆ£Â∏ÉÁ´ûÈÄâJerry NadlerÁöÑÂõΩ‰ºöÂ∏≠‰Ωç
item.description:
City Councilman Erik Bottcher announced his candidacy Thursday for retiring Rep. Jerry Nadler‚Äôs Manhattan congressional seat ‚Äî joining a bevy of wannabes in the Democratic primary including Kennedy scion Jack Schlossberg.

Democrat Bottcher, 46, who is out gay, starts out with a potential base of support with most of his constituents in the neighborhoods of Hudson Square, the West Village, Chelsea, Hudson Yards, Meatpacking District, Garment District, Times Square, and Hell‚Äôs Kitchen also residing in the 12th congressional district.

An upstate native from the North Country, Bottcher said moving to New York City saved his life.

‚ÄúI grew up as a closeted kid in the Adirondack mountains. I was isolated. I was hopeless. I was bullied. I even tried to take my own life,‚Äù Bottcher said in his campaign video.

‚ÄúBut in New York City I found a place that accepted me and I built a life better than I ever dreamed of ‚Ä¶I‚Äôve dedicated my life to giving back to the city that saved mine.‚Äù

He said he now stands up to bullies, and took an obligatory shot at President Trump and Republicans.

His credentials in the LGBT community come in contrast to another candidate eyeing the seat ‚Äî Jack Schlossberg, the grandson of John F. Kennedy ‚Äî who told the New York Times ‚ÄúI am very straight‚Äù when asked about his sexuality.

Other candidates in the race include Assembly members Micah Lasher and Alex Bores, nonprofit Liam Elkind, former financial executive Alan Pardee, and lawyer Jami Floyd.

Lasher has the support of many in Nadler‚Äôs political network.

One prominent LGBT activist said he‚Äôs in Bottcher‚Äôs corner.

Allen Roskoff, who helped write New York City‚Äôs first gay rights law and is president of the Jim Owles LIberal LGBT Democratic Club, said Botcher will ‚Äúoutshine‚Äù his opponents with his ‚Äúintellect, poise, knowledge and resume.‚Äù

‚ÄúErik is an incredible candidate. His one of the smartest men I know. He cares deeply about people. He‚Äôs a progressive and has the record to prove it,‚Äù Roskoff said.

Bottcher has been at the forefront of the LGBT and broader civil rights movement for years, he added.

He served on then-Gov. Andrew Cuomo‚Äôs staff and helped pass the state‚Äôs landmark gay marriage law, before the US Supreme Court legalized same sex nuptials.

‚ÄúEric was among a key group of advisors in the Governor‚Äôs Office who were responsible for the historic passage of the Marriage Equality Act in 2011. He is smart and tenacious but also happens to be a mensch,‚Äù said Steve Cohen, who then served as secretary or top aide to the governor.

‚ÄúMaybe it‚Äôs his Adirondack upbringing that gives him warmth with focused intensity. He knows where he‚Äôs from; he knows who he is; he knows how to serve the public. It‚Äôs hard to think of someone who was a more pleasant and supportive colleague. In the best ways, he‚Äôs brought his own life experiences to bear on his various positions in public service.‚Äù

He‚Äôs not afraid to wade into controversies, recently backing the campaign to ban horse carriages despite industry and union opposition.

Before his election to the council, Bottcher served as chief of staff to former City Council Speaker Corey Johnson.
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.title: Bill de BlasioÁöÑÂçóÂõæÊ£ÆÂ∏ÇÈïøÊúãÂèãRoxanna ValenzuelaÂú®Á†¥ÊóßÁöÑ‰∫öÂà©Ê°ëÈÇ£Â∑ûÊ±ΩËΩ¶ÊóÖÈ¶ÜÁé∞Ë∫´
item.description:
SOUTH TUCSON, Arizona ‚Äî Bill de Blasio‚Äôs latest fling is staying at a shabby South Tucson motel festooned with ‚Äúfree Palestine‚Äù posters and placards in a run-down part of town not far from city hall.

South Tucson Mayor Roxanna Valenzuela, who de Blasio‚Äôs friends say they fear is ‚Äústalking‚Äù the former New York City mayor, has seemingly set up shop at the Arizona Motel.

The motel, built in 1930, was purchased by the Casa Maria Soup Kitchen in 2023 as part of a plan to boost affordable housing in the area, according to KGUN 9.

Valenzuela, 41, works for the soup kitchen, according to the outlet, and The Post spied her entering the Casa Maria building Thursday afternoon after being picked up at the motel by a friend in a white BMW X3.

The fledgling couple ‚Äî who sources say blew up after a brief series of rendezvous, first crossed paths at an Arizona fundraiser in June.

Months later, de Blasio‚Äôs recently jilted ex, progressive activist Nomiki Konst, was contacted by a Pima County official who said Valenzuela wanted to meet with the 64-year-old ex-mayor to discuss Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani.

The former ‚ÄúThe Young Turks‚Äù contributor directed the rep to contact her then-sweetheart directly ‚Äî after which the two started their seamy affair in the Big Apple, sources said.

But their star-crossed romance was apparently not to be. Sources said they‚Äôre no longer on speaking terms ‚Äî however, the apparent split hasn‚Äôt stopped Valenzuela, a mom of two, from continuing to pursue Blaz.

‚ÄúShe was telling people for days after [their tryst] she was going to be with him,‚Äù the source said.

De Blasio even scrapped a recent trip to Puerto Rico for the annual SOMOS political retreat when Valenzuela, a mom of two, flew up to New York City to see him, requiring him to ‚Äúcalm her,‚Äù sources said.

Another source close to the situation spared some concern for the former mayor ‚Äî who is still married to former Big Apple first lady Chirlane McCray ‚Äî as well.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happening with Bill, and now that it‚Äôs out and people close are concerned, it‚Äôs like a mental episode he‚Äôs having, to be honest,‚Äù they said.

Valenzuela declined to comment on the relationship ‚Äî saying ‚Äúnot at this time, I‚Äôm with my kids‚Äù ‚Äî when approached by The Post as she pulled up to the motel in a Ford Explorer.
item.author: Chris Nesi

item.title: ÊçÆÁß∞Á†¥Âùè11ËæÜÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄËΩ¶ËæÜÁöÑÈïøÂ≤õÁî∑Â≠êË¢´ÊçïÔºåÁ´ãÂç≥Âú®Ê≥ïÂ∫≠‰∏äË¢´ÈáäÊîæ
item.description:
A Long Island man who allegedly smashed up and slashed the tires of nearly a dozen police cruisers parked outside the NYPD‚Äôs newest station house was busted after he nearly backed into cops on his tail ‚Äìand then promptly cut loose in court, cops and prosecutors said.

Christian Genwright, 22, of Valley Stream, allegedly defaced five marked and six unmarked NYPD vehicles near the 116th Precinct headquarters on North Conduit Avenue in Rosedale around 11:20 p.m. on Monday ‚Äî then drove off in the luxury getaway car, according to police.

He allegedly used a knife to slash the tires of seven vehicles and smashed the windshields of four others with a hammer ‚Äì causing an airbag to deploy on one, which also had driver‚Äôs side mirror damage, cops and prosecutors said.¬†

Genwright was picked up around 8:40 p.m. Tuesday on 244th Street, where eagle-eyed officers saw the silver Lexus and tried to stop it, but he intentionally reversed, nearly hitting their cruiser, police said.

He was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment, 14 counts of criminal mischief, resisting arrest and two counts of criminal possession of a weapon, police said.¬†

He was arraigned Wednesday night on 10 counts of criminal mischief, according to a criminal complaint.¬†

Genwright was cut loose on supervised release by Judge Jennifer Tubridy because the charges are not eligible for bail under state law, the Queens District Attorney‚Äôs Office said.

He has six prior arrests, the most recent from Feb. 7 for allegedly violating traffic law while driving on the highway, fleeing from police and becoming ‚Äúcombative‚Äù with cops, police said.¬†

He is set to reappear in court on the latest case on Jan. 21, prosecutors said.

The nearly $105 million 116th Precinct station house ‚Äî which¬†opened less than a year ago¬†in December of 2024 ‚Äî is the first entirely new NYPD command established in more than a decade, with the last one opening in 2013.

NYPD officers assigned to the 116th Precinct patrol the neighborhoods of¬†¬†Rosedale, Springfield Gardens, Brookville and Laurelton.
item.author: Amanda Woods

item.title: HochulÊé®ËøüÂØπÊñ∞ÊàøÁöÑÁáÉÊ∞îÁÅ∂Á¶Å‰ª§ÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫ÊîøÂ∫úÂèóÂà∞ÂèåÊñπÁöÑÁÉ≠Èáè
item.description:
Gov. Kathy Hochul is getting cooked for placing her ‚ÄúGreen New Deal‚Äù on the back burner.

The New York leader faced attacks from both sides of the aisle this week when her administration revealed it was stalling the implementation of the All-Electric Buildings Act that includes a controversial ban on installing gas stoves in newly built homes.

The law was supposed to start in January for new buildings up to seven stories, and then for all other buildings in 2029, but state lawyers agreed in a court filing to a delay amid an ongoing court fight challenging the law.

Environmentalists slammed Hochul for pushing off much needed green initiatives while Republicans, like GOP candidate for governor, upstate Rep. Elise Stefanik, accused her of cynically slowing the roll-out ahead of her re-election in 2026.

‚ÄúKathy Hochul is lying to New Yorkers,‚Äù Stefanik bluntly said in a statement.

‚ÄúShe wants them to believe there will not be a gas stove ban and all-electric mandate policies that will absolutely crush New York‚Äôs economy and cause a skyrocketing of prices further worsening the affordability crisis.

‚ÄúThis is a cynical political ‚Äòpause‚Äô so she can screw New Yorkers with higher prices after the election.‚Äù

The congresswoman, who announced her challenge of the Democrat last week, also brought up how Hochul suspended the implementation of congestion pricing for vehicles entering Manhattan‚Äôs business district last year, but reversed course following the 2024 elections.

‚ÄúJust like congestion pricing, when Hochul lied to voters before the election and then immediately raised taxes on workers and commuters, she thinks New Yorkers are stupid and won‚Äôt notice this desperate political ploy,‚Äù she said, adding the gas stove ban should be fully repealed.

Environmental Advocates NY also joined in on slamming Hochul.

‚ÄúDelaying the All Electric Buildings Act will keep us stuck in a fossil fuel past we can‚Äôt afford,‚Äù said Katherine Nadeau, deputy executive director of policy and programs at the organization.

‚ÄúWe need the governor to fight for clean energy, not drag things out further. Every months we wait holds back New York‚Äôs climate progress and puts our future at risk,‚Äù added the green energy activist.

Hochul‚Äôs office said in a statement it was still committed to enforcing the green mandate while pointing to the ongoing court challenge of the law brought by the construction industry including New York State Builders Association, National Association of Home Builders, New York Propane Gas Association and laborers‚Äô unions.

‚ÄúThe governor remains committed to the all-electric-buildings law and believes this action will help the State defend it, as well as reduce regulatory uncertainty for developers during this period of litigation,‚Äù said Ken Lovett, Hochul‚Äôs senior communications adviser on energy and the environment.

‚ÄúGovernor Hochul remains resolved to providing more affordable, reliable, and sustainable energy for New Yorkers.‚Äù

State attorneys said it would not go ahead with the implementation until a federal appellate court delivers a ruling, according to reports.

It‚Äôs just the latest step that Hochul has taken to slow-walk green mandates, and even promote carbon-generating fossil fuels, amid voters‚Äô frustration over rising energy and other costs.

Earlier this year, she delayed implementation of a controversial¬†‚Äúcap and invest‚Äù¬†program that critics warned would send gas and home-heating oil prices soaring.

Hochul last week also greenlit a controversial, President Trump-backed¬†natural-gas pipeline¬†off the Big Apple‚Äôs coast ‚Äì a decision that came after a public push from the White House.

A Democratic pollster said affordability is a more pressing concern with voters than the push for green energy, and Hochul knows it.

‚ÄúGreen energy is on the back burner and bringing prices down is on the front-burner,‚Äù said Evan Roth Smith, a campaign consultant and pollster with Slingshot Strategies.

He noted that Hochul could face a tough re-election fight next year and had a ‚Äúreal scare‚Äù when she won a closer than expected re-election in 2022.

‚ÄúClimate change related policies are not popular when they come into conflict with affordability,‚Äù Smith said.

All New York‚Äôs new green energy mandates, including the separate Climate Protection Act, need to be amended because the mandates are impractical and costly, said Paul Zuber, executive vice president of the NYS Business Council.

Hochul also faces pressure to slow down deadlines to electrify New York‚Äôs car fleet.

The rule requires that 35% of 2026 model cars sold in the state be ‚Äúemissions-free‚Äù and 100% by 2035, though Hochul‚Äôs office said there‚Äôs built-in flexibility to avoid penalties.

‚ÄúWe need to pump the brakes,‚Äù Zuber said.
item.author: Carl Campanile, David Propper

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÂ∏åÊúõÁ§æ‰ºöÂ∑•‰ΩúËÄÖÂìçÂ∫î911ÁîµËØù‚Äî‰ΩÜÊµãËØïËÆ°ÂàíÂ∑≤ÁªèÂ§±Ë¥•
item.description:
Mayor-elect Zohram Mamdani wants to deploy social workers instead of police officers to respond to 911 calls ‚Äî but the controversial plan has already been operating in the Big Apple and is failing.

The early results of a program dubbed B-HEARD spells trouble for Mamdani‚Äôs proposed $1.1 billion Department of Community Safety (DCS), a signature imitative that his newly announced chief of staff and left-hand woman Elle Bisgaard-Church helped craft.

B-HEARD launched in 2021 as a pilot program and only operates in some city neighborhoods, but a bleak audit conducted in May by the city comptroller found it was limping ‚Äî with a whopping 60% of calls deemed ineligible while more than 35% of eligible calls from mental health professionals never got a response.

‚ÄúCalls were considered potentially dangerous, were ineligible because a mental health professional was already at the scene, or were unable to be triaged because FDNY EMS did not take the call or all necessary information could not be collected about the person in distress,‚Äù the comptroller‚Äôs office wrote in a news release at the time.

Between fiscal years 2022 and 2024, the program received a total of 96,291 calls ‚Äî 24,071 of those received a response from a ‚ÄúB-HEARD Team‚Äù which consists of two FDNY officers and EMTS, and one social worker.

The proud socialist mayor-elect is looking to drastically scale up the program ‚Äî which currently consists of 18 active teams ‚Äî through a 150% increase in funding that would place one response squad in each Big Apple neighborhood, and up to three teams in areas with higher need.

Mamdani‚Äôs plan would absorb B-HEARD into the DCS, which his campaign website touts as an agency meant to ‚Äúfill the gaps of our programs and services‚Äù on his campaign website.

‚ÄúIts mission will be to prevent violence before it happens by taking a public health approach to safety,‚Äù the document reads.

Right now, B-HEARD operates in The Bronx, Upper Manhattan, central Brooklyn and a northwest section of Queens. DCS would likely require a massive increase in staffing and resources to scale citywide, experts said.

The pricey project would utilize $605 million by absorbing existing programs like B-HEARD, and seek to raise a whopping $455 million in new funding.

Mamdani‚Äôs DCS plan has alienated law enforcement, with critics saying it could not only put potential callers in harm‚Äôs way but endanger the responders.

Experts interviewed by The Post echoed said B-HEARD‚Äôs questionable effectiveness was a bad sign for a potential DCS.

‚ÄúThe devil is in the details, and here the detail is implementation. The fact that the program is not reaching people does not tell me it‚Äôs unsuccessful; that is a matter of resources,‚Äù said Richard Aborn, president of the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City.

‚ÄúBut there are fundamental questions,‚Äù he said, noting the harrowing idea of when it‚Äôs appropriate to send mental health professionals to 911 calls instead of law enforcement.

Political strategist Hank Sheinkopf scoffed at the idea of a new department entirely.

‚ÄúExactly what New York doesn‚Äôt need: another government agency with an unmanageable bureaucracy. Domestic dispute calls can get violent,‚Äù Sheinkopf emphasized.

That‚Äôs the time when you need a social worker? He must be kidding,‚Äù said the politico.

Political veteran Bill Cunningham, who once served under Mayor Michael Bloomberg, emphasized the program‚Äôs need for ‚Äústronger management.‚Äù

‚ÄúI think it might be wiser, and probably easier to take this report and fix the issues,‚Äù Cunningham said.

‚ÄúThe bottom line should be how to deliver the needed services. If the corrections are not made, then everything else is cosmetic,‚Äù he said.
item.author: Hannah Fierick, Matthew Fischetti

item.title: Zohran MamdaniÁªà‰∫éÈ¢ÑËÆ¢‰∫Ü‚ÄúÊú™Êù•Âá†Âë®‚Äù‰∏éÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂ±ÄÂßîÂëòJessica TischÁöÑ‰ºöÈù¢ÔºöÊ∂àÊÅØÊù•Ê∫ê
item.description:
Meet the big 5-0, Zoh.

Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani finally has a meeting booked with NYPD Commissioner Jessica Tisch in the ‚Äúcoming weeks,‚Äù sources said ‚Äî ending the wait for possible proof he‚Äôll hold onto the promised powwow.

Mamdani has pledged to keep the well-regarded, tough-on-crime Tisch as his top cop, a move that has helped assuage some fears over his public safety priorities, given he called the NYPD ‚Äúracist‚Äù in 2020.

A lineup of powerful New Yorkers ‚Äî such as Gov. Kathy Hochul, House Minority Leader¬†Hakeem Jeffries (D-Brooklyn) and business community bigwig Kathy Wylde ‚Äî as well as police unions have both publicly and privately¬†pushed the socialist to keep Tisch.

And Tisch herself is facing pressure to take Mamdani‚Äôs offer, sources have said.

But the police commish could very well end up being an odd fit in Mamdani‚Äôs incoming socialist administration, beyond being a billionaire heiress.

She has vocally opposed aspects of criminal justice reforms that Mamdani supports and backed her current boss Mayor Eric Adams‚Äô plan to increase the NYPD‚Äôs headcount to 40,000 officers.

Mamdani has said he intends to keep the headcount at its current depleted level of 34,000.

Tisch, however, has capably served in several mayoral administrations and could very well find herself at home among the veterans of Bill de Blasio‚Äôs City Hall who so far are filling up the ranks around the incoming mayor.

An NYPD spokesperson referred The Post to Mamdani‚Äôs transition team for questions about Tisch‚Äôs meeting with the mayor-elect. The transition team didn‚Äôt immediately respond to a request for comment.
item.author: Matthew Fischetti, Matt Troutman

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Â∏ÇÂ∏ÇÈïøÂüÉÈáåÂÖã¬∑‰∫öÂΩìÊñØÔºà Eric Adams ÔºâÂ∞ÜZohran MamdaniÁöÑÊé•ÂäõÊ£í--‰ª•ÂèäÈáçÂ§ßÂÜ≥Á≠ñ--‰∫§Áªô‰∫ÜÂõ¢Èòü
item.description:
They‚Äôre tag-teaming the transition.

Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani‚Äôs transition team met with their counterparts in outgoing Hizzoner Eric Adams‚Äô administration Wednesday ‚Äî as their bosses respectively trade barbs.

Adams revealed the crucial powwow during an unrelated Thursday event in Manhattan, promising a smooth transfer of power to his socialist successor even as he leaves him with some big decisions and sets up obstacles to his agenda.

‚ÄúBill de Blasio handed me the baton of dealing with these issues, and I‚Äôm going to hand the baton over to Zohran,‚Äù the mayor said.

‚ÄúOur transition team met with his team yesterday, and, you know, we‚Äôre turning over a wealth of information so they can make the decisions.‚Äù

But the business-as-usual tone Adams struck not only contrasted with his dire warnings about Mamdani before Election Day, but also his out-the-door attempts to stymie the incoming mayor.

Adams in recent weeks has moved to pack a crucial board in a bid to forestall a rent freeze, pushed to increase the NYPD‚Äôs headcount and declared the celeb-beloved Elizabeth Street garden a park ‚Äî all of which are at odds with Mamdani‚Äôs stances.

A frustrated Mamdani admitted Thursday that Adams‚Äô move on Elizabeth Street likely will tie his hands, contending it will make it ‚Äúnearly impossible‚Äù to build affordable housing at the Nolita haven.

‚ÄúIt is no surprise that Mayor Adams is using his final week months to cement a legacy of dysfunction and inconsistency,‚Äù he said.

Within breaths of dissing Adams, Mamdani did take time to praise the mayor‚Äôs team as ‚Äúcollaborative‚Äù during the transition.

The two transition teams met at City Hall, with Adams‚Äô chief staff and handover boss Camille Joseph-Varlack taking part, sources said.

And there are signs the collaborative spirit between the two sides runs deeper than the testy relationship between Adams and Mamdani.

Sources said multiple members of Adams‚Äô communications team have explicitly reached out for a new gig with Mamdani.

‚ÄúWe had a very productive meeting and we look forward to continuing to work closely with the Mayor‚Äôs team on a smooth transition,‚Äù said Dora Pekec, a spokeswoman for Mamdani‚Äôs transition team.
item.author: Matthew Fischetti, Matt Troutman

item.title: Ê±§ÂßÜ¬∑Â∏ÉÈõ∑Ëø™Ôºà Tom Brady ÔºâÁöÑÁ∫ΩÁ∫¶Âç°ÁâåÂïÜÂ∫óÊä¢Ëµ∞‰∫ÜËøë$ 1‰∏áÁæéÂÖÉÁöÑÊ£íÁêÉ„ÄÅÂè£Ë¢ãÂ¶ñÊÄ™Âç°Áâå
item.description:
A slick thief made off with nearly $10,000 in baseball and Pokemon cards from a SoHo shop owned by NFL legend Tom Brady, cops said.

The still-at-large crook ‚Äî seen in surveillance footage wearing a Yankees cap ‚Äî entered CardVault by Tom Brady on Lafayette Street near Prince Street and tried to buy merch using a credit card in the Oct. 20 heist, police said Thursday.

When his card was declined, he fudged with the tap-to-pay system to trick the employee into believing the transaction went through, authorities said.

He then left with a haul of baseball and Pokemon cards worth $9,710, police said.

Police could not confirm what specific cards he‚Äôd stolen, and the store declined to comment.

‚ÄúNo kidding. That‚Äôs not nice. That happens with the city,‚Äù shopper Samantha Castaneda said of the theft as she headed out the store with her grandson.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs terrible. The people feel like the card has value. It‚Äôs not just the money. People really love it, that‚Äôs why they buy it. I hope they find the guy.‚Äù

The suspect, seen inside the store in a video released by the NYPD Thursday, is described as a male with a medium complexion.

In addition to the baseball cap, he was last seen wearing a black hooded sweatshirt, black shorts, white socks, white sneakers and carrying a multicolored bag with what appears to be a cartoon image.

Anyone with information on his whereabouts is asked to call the NYPD‚Äôs Crime Stoppers Hotline at 1-800-577-TIPS (8477) or for Spanish, 1-888-57-PISTA (74782).
item.author: Joe Marino, Steven Vago, Amanda Woods

item.title: ÊãøÈ™öÈ´òÁÆ°Â∏ÉÈ≤ÅÊñØ¬∑Â∏ÉËé±ÂÖãÊõºÔºà Bruce Blakeman ÔºâËÆ§‰∏∫ÂÖ±ÂíåÂÖöÂ∑ûÈïøÁ´ûÈÄâ‰∏çÂ∫îÂèòÊàêÂç°È©¨ÊãâÂºèÁöÑ‚ÄúÂä†ÂÜïÁ§º‚Äù
item.description:
Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman blasted the state GOP boss for saying there‚Äôd be no primary for governor ‚Äì warning the race could turn into a Kamala Harris-style ‚Äúcoronation.‚Äù

Blakeman, who‚Äôs eyeing a run for the nomination, had harsh words for Republican Party Chairman Ed Cox who threw his full support behind upstate Rep. Elise Stefanik as she launched her gubernatorial campaign last week.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know who appointed him the king of the Republican Party,‚Äù Blakeman said of Cox as he kicked off a speaking tour across the Empire State at the American Legion in Massapequa.

‚ÄúBut I can tell you this, we are not going to have a coronation like they had for Kamala Harris in the Democratic Party. That‚Äôs not what the Republican Party‚Äôs about.‚Äù¬†

Harris, the former vice president, was quickly anointed the Democratic nominee to face Donald Trump last year after then-President Biden dropped under pressure after primaries had already been held.

Cox had praised Stefanik in a statement after she announced she was running against Democratic Gov. Kathy Hochul.

‚ÄúThere will not be a Republican primary and a year from now, Elise will lead our team to victory over Kathy Hochul, end one-party Democrat rule, and make New York affordable again,‚Äù he said.

But Blakeman, fresh off a commanding re-election win on Long Island, insisted competition is good.

‚ÄúI think we have to have competition, we have to see who‚Äôs the best candidate ‚Äî and if it‚Äôs somebody else, that‚Äôs great, I‚Äôm fine, I can live with that,‚Äù he said Thursday while not mentioning Stefanik by name.

‚ÄúBut we shouldn‚Äôt coronate somebody, we should see who‚Äôs the best and strongest candidate to win and beat Kathy Hochul ‚Äî and a lot of people are telling me, it‚Äôs me.‚Äù¬†

A spokesperson for the state GOP stood by Stefanik in a statement to The Post. ¬†

‚ÄúCounty Executive Blakeman has earned widespread respect for his strong leadership on Long Island. Elise Stefanik announced¬†her candidacy along with the endorsement of an overwhelming majority of County Chairs around the state,‚Äù the spokesperson said. ¬†

‚ÄúWe have every expectation that she will be our candidate, we will avoid a primary and we will defeat Kathy Hochul a year from now, giving¬†New Yorkers new leadership that prioritizes affordability and economic opportunity.‚Äù

Stefanik‚Äôs spokesperson said ‚Äúon day one‚Äù the congresswoman earned ‚Äúover 70% of the weighted vote of GOP county chairs and the support of the Conservative Party.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt is unfortunate that this prospective candidate is already attacking Republican county chairs and state officials across New York when they are more unified than ever in their mission to fire Kathy Hochul,‚Äù spokesperson Berndadette Breslin said.

‚ÄúElise is the only candidate in this race who has won every primary and general election, and she has done so by unifying Republicans, Independents, and Democrats with the highest voter turnout in the state. Her support is only going to continue to climb. Elise already is the most well-funded candidate and highest polling candidate in history, and that will continue to climb. And everyone knows it.‚Äù

Blakeman‚Äôs was set to make stops in Newburgh, Albany and then the tippy-top of the state in Plattsburgh on Thursday. He also chatted with New York City business leaders Wednesday.

He has touted his appeal to independent and Democratic voters that will need to back a Republican to defeat Hochul. He‚Äôs also said he‚Äôll reach a decision about whether to jump in the race in the near future.

Both Blakeman and Stefanik have assailed Hochul‚Äôs left-leaning policies and are ardent supporters of President Trump, who has praised both of them during their careers in public service.

‚ÄúCan we change our state? Can we make our state a better place to live? Yes,‚Äù Blakeman said.
item.author: Brandon Cruz, David Propper

item.title: Âú®‚Äú‰∏ëÈôã‚ÄùÁöÑÂ∏ÉÈ≤ÅÂÖãÊûóÂ∫óÈù¢‰∏ãÂèëÁé∞ÁôæÂπ¥ÂéÜÂè≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Ëâ≤ÁéªÁíÉ
item.description:
This therapist unlocked a piece of history.

Construction crews working on a refreshed storefront for a Brooklyn psychotherapy office discovered stunning, century-old stained glass that offers a sneak peek into Greenpoint‚Äôs past.

‚ÄúI was totally blown away. It‚Äôs a huge unexpected gift,‚Äù Karen G. Costa, who has rented Brooklyn Psychotherapy‚Äôs office at 705 Manhattan Ave. for years, told The Post.

‚ÄúI almost cried.‚Äù

The incredible find was made last month after Costa hired construction crews to revamp what she called the ‚Äúugly‚Äù Greenpoint storefront that made her therapy office look more like a jail cell.

She had hoped they would replace the corrugated metal and gates with wood paneling akin to a retro, but traditional therapy office ‚Äî and was repaid with an even more vintage result.

Three separate panels stretch across the storefront windows in white, green and black glass, reading ‚Äúperfumes,‚Äù ‚Äútoilet articles‚Äù and ‚Äúprescriptions,‚Äù as first reported by Forgotten New York.

The styled glass perfectly matches the massive ‚Äú706‚Äù attached to its neighboring door that leads to the apartments above the therapy office that has been on display for decades ‚Äî as well as the original drugstore sign that Costa‚Äôs landlord had stashed in the basement.

A 1940 tax photo shows the beautiful stained glass that once adorned a business by the name of John H. Wienholz‚Äôs Drug Store.

Archival newspapers show adverts for the shop dating as far back as 1920.

Wienholz made his own cough medication, according to Forgotten New York.

It‚Äôs not clear when the drug store shuttered, but a tax photo from the 1980s shows that an auto parts store had taken its place.

Several people have already tried to buy the incredible find off Costa and her contractors, with one person offering a wild $18,000 for the panels ‚Äî but the therapist said it‚Äôs a finders-keepers situation.

‚ÄúI want my patients to have a welcome space. It‚Äôs such a nice surprise,‚Äù the Greenpointer explained.¬†

She has restored the three small broken pieces, but said the glass, while paper-thin, is in impeccable condition.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶ËÇ°‰ªΩÂÖ¨Âè∏Âà©ËíÇË•ø‰∫ö¬∑Ë©πÂßÜÊñØÔºà Letitia James ÔºâÂ®ÅËÉÅÂ∫∑Ê≥∞Á∫≥‰ªïÔºà Cond√© Nast ÔºâÂØπ‚ÄúËß£ÈõáÂõõ‰∫∫‚ÄùÊèêËµ∑Ê≥ïÂæãËØâËÆºÔºåÂêéËÄÖ‰∏é‰∫∫ÂäõËµÑÊ∫ê‰∏ªÁÆ°Â∞±
item.description:
New¬†York Attorney General¬†Letitia James¬†threatened to take Cond√© Nast to court over the ‚ÄúFired Four‚Äù on Wednesday night during a union rally outside the company‚Äôs World Trade Center headquarters.

Cond√© Nast angered the NewsGuild of¬†New York¬†last week by firing four employees after they confronted the company‚Äôs HR chief outside his C-suite office to ‚Äúdemand answers‚Äù on recent layoffs at WIRED and Teen Vogue.¬†

The Guild blasted the firings as ‚Äúgrossly illegal tactics‚Äù designed to union-bust and intimidate and organized a rally to call for the reinstatement of the group that has been billed as the ‚ÄúFired Four‚Äù by colleagues.¬†

NewsGuild of New York President Susan DeCarava introduced James to rallygoers by declaring she has ‚Äúbuilt her career on standing up for working people‚Äù and ‚Äúholding powerful interests to account.‚Äù

James came to the podium and started chants of, ‚ÄúWhen we fight, we win,‚Äù and ‚ÄúPeople, united, will never be defeated,‚Äù before suggesting the economy is ‚Äúrigged against working people.‚Äù¬†

James told the assembled crowd she was proud to stand with the Guild before asking, ‚ÄúSince when is it illegal for an individual, or individuals, to express, or recognize, their First Amendment rights? Since when is that illegal? When is it illegal to ask a question? When is it illegal to speak truth to power? When is it illegal to get answers from your employer?‚Äù

James, who is fighting her own battle right now after pleading not guilty to federal bank fraud charges, accused Cond√© Nast of skirting labor protections.¬†

‚ÄúTo all of those who are responsible for the termination of these individuals, let me introduce myself. My name is Letitia James, otherwise known as Tish, and I am here to let you know that I stand with workers now, and I will stand with workers forever,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúI want you to know that I‚Äôm not afraid to march into a courtroom to assure that the rights of these individuals, and the rights of all workers, is respected and honored. And that the rule of law is on the side of those individuals who simply asked the question, ‚ÄòWhat is going on?‚Äô So, I urge you, I urge you now, to reverse these terminations,‚Äù James continued. ‚ÄúThis is an injustice. My name is Letitia James and as the Attorney General of the State of New York, Cond√© Nast, I‚Äôll see you in court.‚Äù¬†

Cond√© Nast appeared unfazed by James‚Äô threat, insisting the ‚ÄúFired Four‚Äù had been terminated lawfully.

‚ÄúThe employment¬†terminations were lawful and based on clear violations of company policies. We have an obligation to protect our workplace from harassment and intimidation. If the Attorney General has concerns, we are happy to respond to her,‚Äù a Cond√© Nast spokesperson told Fox News Digital.¬†

The dispute began last week when staffers confronted Cond√© Nast Chief People Officer Stan Duncan, peppering him with questions about the recent layoffs.

Duncan urged them to return to their workspaces immediately.¬†

The caught-on-camera interaction resulted in the termination of four of the employees involved.¬†

Bon App√©tit digital producer Alma Avalle, who is also a NewsGuild of New York leader and trans activist, was fired, along with Wired senior White House reporter Jake Lahut, The New Yorker senior fact-checker Jasper Lo and Cond√© Nast Entertainment videographer Ben Dewey.¬†

A Cond√© Nast insider told Fox News Digital that several minutes of the incident are missing from the viral video that show the workers being more disruptive.¬†

Cond√© Nast and the Guild have each filed unfair-labor-practice charges against each other.¬†

The Cond√© Nast insider also told¬†Fox News Digital¬†that the company has filed three previous grievances this year with the union about similar behavior.¬†

James has long-drawn President¬†Donald Trump‚Äôs ire after she campaigned for attorney general in 2018 largely on vows to investigate Trump‚Äôs actions and businesses.

The rally came after DeCarava told Fox News Digital that, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want employers to think that just because the Trump administration seems hell-bent on demonizing the press and doing away with free press and finding ways to inhibit an independent press, and free speech that the employer should then use that as an excuse to basically ignore or abrogate the collective bargaining agreements we‚Äôve reached with them.‚Äù

Cond√© Nast maintains staffers were terminated for cause.

‚ÄúMost people recognize that the misconduct exhibited¬†by union members last week wouldn‚Äôt be acceptable in any workplace. Their employment was terminated with cause, as they were in violation of our company policies. Blaming the ramifications of their own¬†misconduct on the Trump administration is pretty absurd,‚Äù a Cond√© Nast spokesperson told Fox News Digital prior to the rally.¬†

The layoffs that irked the ‚ÄúFired Four‚Äù in the first place included an announcement that Teen Vogue would transition from a separate publication to being part of Vogue.com.

The headcount reduction that came with the change caught the attention of the Guild, which noted the left-wing outlet was laying off minorities and transgender people.
item.author: Fox Business

item.title: Á∫ΩÁ∫¶Ë≠¶ÂØüÂú®ÂøÉË∑≥Âä†ÈÄüÁöÑÊïëÊè¥Ë°åÂä®‰∏≠‰ªéÂìàËé±ÂßÜÊ≤≥ÊïëËµ∑Â∞ëÂ•≥ÔºöËßÜÈ¢ë
item.description:
Three NYPD cops pulled a teen girl from the freezing Harlem River during a dramatic caught-on-camera rescue Tuesday ‚Äî with one of the hero officers stating, ‚ÄúNothing else mattered but just getting her out of the water.‚Äù¬†

Uptown Manhattan police officers¬†Ankit Gupta, Wilmer Guerrero¬†and Shuaibul Amine were all lauded Thursday for their quick work after the young victim initially jumped into the chilly waters in what sources said was an apparent suicide attempt ‚Äî and quickly regretted her near-fatal plunge.

‚ÄúSomebody needed help, and this is what we signed up for, and we‚Äôre here to help, and that‚Äôs what we did,‚Äù Guerrero said.

Guerrero stripped off most of her gear and jacket to dive into the river and retrieved the teenager while two other cops were ready to yank the pair up to the shore near 142nd Street around 2 p.m., according to body camera footage.

‚ÄúIt was definitely a cold plunge, freezing. But at that moment, nothing else mattered but just getting her out of the water. So I got over it pretty quickly,‚Äù Guerrero recalled back near the scene of the rescue Thursday with Gupta and Anime.

‚ÄúI just grabbed her by her sweater and her shoulder, and I was just swimming along with her, and then I was just pushing her forward.

‚ÄúI was having a hard time because she was in such a panic frenzy. But I just kept my composure, saying encouraging words that we‚Äôre going get through this.‚Äù¬†

The heart-pounding moment began after authorities received a call about girl in distress attempting to jump off the Harlem River Drive. As cops converged on the area and started running toward her on the rocks, she ‚Äújust jumped into the water, with all her clothes on,‚Äù Gupta said.

The girl instantly began to desperately wail and screamed ‚Äúhelp me, help me, please!‚Äù

As Guerrero readied himself to jump in, another cop asked, ‚ÄúCan you swim? Can you swim?‚Äù

Guerrero reached the girl, who was about 20 feet away, within seconds and helped get her back to shore.

Gupta and Amine, who also shed some of his gear in case he needed to also jump in, then pulled the pair back to safe ground, according to the bodycam footage.

The girl was quickly wrapped around with blankets once the Emergency Service Unit team reached the scene and an ambulance later brought her to a hospital conscious and alert.

‚ÄúAnd hopefully we gave this girl a second chance, because obviously this thing could have gone a whole different way,‚Äù Guerrero said.

The three cops all work for the 32nd precinct and each have less than four years on the job. It was the trio‚Äôs first water rescue and a benchmark of their promising careers.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm just glad that we were all there as a group, that it was a group effort that gave her a second chance,‚Äù said Gupta as Anime added, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs great when you save somebody. That‚Äôs what we signed up for in this job, right?‚Äù
item.author: Reuven Fenton, Amanda Woods, David Propper

item.title: Ê≥ïÂæãÊè¥Âä©ÂæãÂ∏àÂ∑•‰ºöÂú®3ÂêçÊàêÂëòÊçÆÁß∞Ë¢´Âò≤Á¨ëÂêéËææÊàêÂíåËß£ÔºåÊàê‰∏∫‰∫≤‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóÁ´ãÂú∫ÁöÑÁõÆÊ†á
item.description:
The union repping taxpayer-funded Legal Aid lawyers agreed to settle a discrimination lawsuit brought by members who were allegedly ridiculed and targeted for opposing a union-approved anti-Israel resolution as antisemitic.

The Association of Legal Aid Attorneys, UAW Local 2325, agreed to pay the three pro-Israel members a total of $315,000 and admitted that some of the comments leveled at the trio were ‚Äúinappropriate.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre happy for our clients, and for the precedent this settlement establishes for Jewish and allied union members across the country laboring against an obsessive focus on demonizing Israel and Jews, instead of a focus on fighting for better wages, benefits and working conditions,‚Äù said Rory Lancman, director of corporate initiatives & senior Counsel at the Brandeis Center, who led the prosecution for the plaintiffs.

The settlement also calls for mandatory training of union members.

The case was brought by the Louis Brandeis Center for Human Rights Under Law, a Jewish legal civil rights group.

The ALAA had even initiated proceedings to expel the three Nassau County members ‚Äî Ilana Kopmar, Diane Clarke and Isaac Altman ‚Äî after they filed a lawsuit last year to block the union from passing a one-sided resolution that condemned Israel for the war, but didn‚Äôt blame Hamas, whose Oct. 7, 2023 terror attacks sparked the conflict.

Two of three plaintiffs are Jewish.

The approved resolution also opposes all existing and future US military aid to Israel and endorses the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement against the Jewish state, which critics say is a form of antisemitism.

In their federal court complaint, the plaintiffs described being targeted as ‚Äúsnitches,‚Äù ‚Äúlosers,‚Äù ‚Äúdisgusting,‚Äù ‚Äúdictators in training‚Äù and ‚ÄúZionist ghouls‚Äù in the ALAA‚Äôs internal discussion boards.

Plaintiff Ilana Kopmar said she and the others fought the union for passing ‚Äúan antisemitic resolution.‚Äù

‚ÄúThey retaliated, tried to silence and bully us. I‚Äôm proud that me and my co-plaintiffs fought, and I‚Äôm hoping that with this resolution the union will think twice about retaliating against their members,‚Äù Kopmar said.

Plaintiff Isaac Altman said he‚Äôll be donating a portion of his settlement payout to the Israeli emergency medical services group Magen David Adom.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy to be done with this chapter and of the work we did to stand up for ourselves and our people,‚Äù he said.

By passing the divisive Israel-bashing resolution, the ALAA defied the policy of its employer ‚Äî the Legal Aid Society, which receives hundreds of millions of dollars in city and state funding. The society has a policy of steering clear of taking stands on international political conflicts.

The Legal Aid Society blasted the controversial resolution as ‚Äúladen with coded antisemitic language and thinly veiled calls for the destruction of the State of Israel.‚Äù

Kenneth Marcus, chairman of the Brandeis Center, likened union anti-Israel hostility and even antisemitism to Jew-bashing on college campuses.

‚ÄúWe are seeing an increasing trend in labor union anti-Semitism, much as we have seen a similar increase on college campuses. In both cases, there is bitter irony,‚Äù said Marcus, a former US Assistant Secretary of Education who ran the Office for Civil Rights.

‚ÄúColleges are supposed to be islands of reason and tolerance. Labor unions are supposed to be advocates for social justice and workplace equality,‚Äù Marcus added.

‚ÄúTo find the oldest hatred in such places is deeply antithetical to their mission. This settlement is a landmark in the fight against anti-Semitism in this sector.‚Äù

The ALAA union had no immediate comment.

But in the court-approved settlement, the union stated, ‚ÄúWe acknowledge that some of the communications from diverse perspectives were hurtful to union members and inappropriate.‚Äù
item.author: Carl Campanile

item.description:
Staten Island drivers could get the green light to turn on red under a new bill proposed Thursday by borough councilman Frank Morano ‚Äî which he argues will cut down congestion and speed up commutes.

Making a right turn on a red light is illegal in New York City unless a sign explicitly permits it, despite a law allowing the maneuver in the rest of the Empire State.

‚ÄúStaten Islanders spend far too much time waiting at empty intersections where a safe right turn could be made,‚Äù Morano said in a statement.¬†

‚ÄúThis is about data and common sense ‚Äî not guesswork.‚Äù

The councilman argued that allowing drivers to turn on red will reduce congestion, cut down on emissions, and considerably shorten commute times.

The state law was introduced in 1977 and was designed to do just that ‚Äî save energy and reduce idling pollution, according to a New York Times report at the time.¬†

Some intersections on Staten Island already permit the maneuver, but the NYC Department of Transportation (DOT) requires a traffic study to be performed before it can be allowed at new intersections.

Morano‚Äôs bill, Intro 1469, would require the DOT to conduct a study on the feasibility and safety of allowing right turns on red following a complete stop at each intersection in the borough with a traffic control signal.

‚ÄúIf there are intersections where right turns on red can be done safely, then Staten Islanders deserve that efficiency,‚Äù Morano said.

‚ÄúIf there are places where it can‚Äôt be done safely, then we leave those alone. It‚Äôs that simple.‚Äù¬†

The study would consider the turning patterns of larger vehicles and the impact of the maneuver on pedestrians, cyclists, traffic and the environment.

Under Morano‚Äôs bill, the DOT would issue a progress update within six months and a final report within one year.

The proposal, referred to the council‚Äôs committee on Transportation and Infrastructure on Thursday, has already received bipartisan support from fellow Staten Island reps David M. Carr and Kamillah Hanks.¬†

‚ÄúThis is a common-sense bill that will make traffic move quicker in a borough where we depend on our cars to get around,‚Äù Carr said.

Morano and Carr slammed the one-size-fits-all approach to New York City‚Äôs right-on-red rules in a joint statement, arguing their constituents have different needs due to Staten Island‚Äôs ‚Äúunique transportation reality‚Äù and abundance of drivers.

Nearly 85% of Staten Island households own a vehicle, compared to 63% of Queens and 44% of Brooklyn households, according to figures from Hunter Urban Policy & Planning at Hunter College.

‚ÄúStaten Islanders have dealt with a slew of unnecessary restrictions on their primary mode of transportation for decades,‚Äù Carr said.¬†

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time we take a step in the right direction and free up the roadways on the island.‚Äù¬†
item.author: Nicole Rosenthal
