item.description:
The Brooklyn building super who died in a scuffle with a porch pirate Wednesday was remembered by grieving family as a Kosovo war refugee and devoted father of three ‚Äî as his alleged killer waits to face charges.

Burim Havolli, 41, was beaten to death while defending his Ditmas Park building, which has recently been plagued by package thefts and outside troublemakers, neighbors and relatives said.

‚ÄúHe died protecting the building, protecting the packages of the tenants,‚Äù his brother, Belerim Havolli, told The Post. ‚ÄúHe cares so much about everyone here. He had a big heart. He was just unbelievable.

‚ÄúHe was a very nice family man. I feel so bad for his wife and children,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúWhat is this world coming to today? These are babies he had and now they‚Äôre going to grow up without a father.‚Äù

Charges are still pending for the 30-year-old assailant, who was arrested shortly after the assault.

‚ÄúThey need to be convicted,‚Äù longtime tenant Ingrid Compton, 70, said. ‚ÄúThey need to be put away. They need to make an example out of him.‚Äù

Law enforcement sources said the alleged attack, who has not been officially charged, has at least three prior arrests, including a burglary rap last year and assault busts last year and in 2017.

Carolyn Banfield, the mother of the suspect‚Äôs ex, said the couple parted ways after a tumultuous relationship.

‚ÄúHe was very jealous,‚Äù Banfield said. ‚ÄúI would say it was jealousy because some men are really demanding with women sometimes.‚Äù

It is unclear what charges he may face in Havolli‚Äôs death, which could depend on autopsy results.

Meanwhile, the slain super will have his funeral service in his native Kosovo, the family said on Facebook.

‚ÄúI would like to inform all friends and relatives that suddenly a few moments ago my son, brother, father and our dearest Burim Havolli passed away,‚Äù the post said. ‚ÄúHe migrated to the USA, where I work and create a family and left behind his wife Jehona, children, Joni, Dhurata and Kroni.‚Äù

Havolli was at the Ditmas Park apartment building around 8 a.m. Wednesday when he confronted the 30-year-old suspect who was allegedly attempting to steal a tenant‚Äôs package ‚Äî a constant nuisance in the building, sources and neighbors said.

The goon struck Havolli in the head with his phone several times, with the super collapsing.

Havolli was rushed to Kings County Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead.

The Albanian refugee had been watching over the building for more than 15 years, and spoke to The Post in 2013 after a nurse lived in was involved in a gruesome attempted murder suicide.

Havolli recalled walking in on the gory scene where Anna Thomas, 20, allegedly killed her 19-month-old son and tried to kill herself ‚Äî telling reporters he was shocked by the crime.

Locals said he has remained protective of the building and it‚Äôs tenants.

‚ÄúWe survived the war as a refugee,‚Äù his brother said. ‚ÄúMy mother, she was sick for two years. Even now she‚Äôs sick‚Ä¶he went back home to see her. He said, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm going just to see her because I don‚Äôt know if she‚Äôs going to make it till next time.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúHe traveled back from Europe two days before this happened. He just went to see her,‚Äù the sibling said. ‚ÄúHe said, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know if she‚Äôs going to make it.‚Äô‚Äù
item.author: Steven Vago, Joe Marino, Jorge Fitz-Gibbon

item.description:
A violent person attempted to confront acting US Attorney for the District of New Jersey Alina Habba before allegedly vandalizing her office, Attorney General Pam Bondi announced Thursday, adding the the Justice department was searching for the suspect.

‚ÄúLast night, an individual attempted to confront one of our U.S. Attorneys ‚Äî my dear friend¬†@USAttyHabba¬†‚Äîdestroyed property in her office, and then fled the scene. Thankfully, Alina is ok,‚Äù¬†Bondi wrote on X.

‚ÄúAny violence or threats of violence against any federal officer will not be tolerated. Period. This is unfortunately becoming a trend as radicals continue to attack law enforcement agents around the country.‚Äù

Habba, who oversees all federal criminal prosecutions and civil litigations in the Garden State, reshared Bondi‚Äôs post, asserting: ‚ÄúI will not be intimidated by radical lunatics for doing my job.‚Äù
item.author: Anna Young

item.title: ÁªùÊúõÁöÑÊîØÊåÅËÄÖÊï¶‰øÉÈáäÊîæÂõ†ËÆøÈóÆ‰ª•Ëâ≤ÂàóËÄåË¢´‰ºäÊúóÁõëÁ¶ÅÁöÑÊÇ£ÊúâÁôåÁóáÁöÑÊùéÁè†ÂÆùÂïÜ
item.description:
A big-hearted, cancer-stricken Long Island jeweler has been jailed in Iran for the alleged crime of visiting Israel 13 years ago ‚Äî leaving his increasingly desperate family pleading for his release.

Kamran Hekmati, 70, a dual US and Iranian citizen, was rounded up by the saber-rattling regime in the spring, during one of his many travels back to his beloved home country, his cousin Shohreh Nowfar¬†told The Post.

Iranian officials eventually sent Hekmati to the notoriously brutal Evin Prison as punishment for his Israel trip, during which he had attended his son‚Äôs bar mitzvah.

The ongoing Kafka-by-way-of-Tehran nightmare prompted Hekmati‚Äôs family and Rep. Tom Suozzi (D-Long Island) to push Secretary of State Marco Rubio for help.

‚ÄúHe just wants to come home,‚Äù Nowfar said. ‚ÄúAnytime he talks, he says ‚ÄòGet me out of here.‚Äô‚Äù

Hekmati, a Persian Jew, immigrated to the US when he was roughly 13 years ago, but never lost ties to Iran, Nowfar said.

Even as Hekmati built a new American life ‚Äî running a Diamond District business, thriving in Long Island‚Äôs large Persian Jewish community and sitting on the Great Neck Estates Zoning Board of Appeals ‚Äî he regularly returned to his home country for sometimes months-long vacations and family trips, his cousin said.

‚ÄúHe absolutely loved Iran,‚Äù Nowfar said. ‚ÄúHe goes two, three times a year. He has a lot of friends there.‚Äù

Before Hekmati‚Äôs fateful spring trip to Iran, he underwent surgery and chemotherapy for aggressive bladder cancer.

Nowfar, who lives in Los Angeles, said Hekmati has to receive treatment every three months ‚Äî but that fell into limbo when Iranian authorities first confiscated his passport and then ultimately sentenced him to prison.

‚ÄúThe government says that his sentence is because he went to Israel, or what they call occupied land, seven years ago,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúBut in reality, he went there 13 years ago, not seven years ago, and the law passed about going to Israel, about six, seven years ago. So, he went there before the law passed in Iran. That was for his son‚Äôs bar mitzvah.‚Äù

Hekmati‚Äôs sentence was originally four years, but has since been reduced to two, the New York Times first reported.

He‚Äôs also one of four Americans being held by Iran, the Times reported.

Nowfar said Hekmati is only able to contact family through friends and his Iranian lawyer ‚Äî and they don‚Äôt even know what part of Evin prison he‚Äôs in, or if he‚Äôs getting proper medical care.

‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt allow any outside doctor to go to the prisoner,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt know what the situation is with the prison‚Äôs hospital. But as far as I know he hasn‚Äôt been getting the quarterly treatment he needs.‚Äù¬†

The dire situation prompted Suozzi this week to send a formal letter to Secretary of State Marco Rubio, calling for immediate action.

‚ÄúThis case is deeply troubling,‚Äù Suozzi said in a statement.

‚ÄúMr. Hekmati is a cherished member of the Long Island community. He is not only a respected public servant serving on the Great Neck Estates Zoning Board of Appeals, but he is also battling an aggressive form of bladder cancer. He must be released immediately on humanitarian grounds.‚Äù

Hekmani‚Äôs family ‚Äî who, aside from Nowfar, declined to comment ‚Äî has also been in touch with Rubio‚Äôs office and foreign dignitaries, his cousin said.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre hoping that they can do something about it,‚Äù Nowfar said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just sitting tight and hoping. He is a very kind, very big-hearted person. And he tries to help anybody in distress.

‚ÄúThe irony is that the country that he loved so much, the country that he adored so much, took him to prison.‚Äù
item.author: Reuven Fenton, Matt Troutman

item.title: Â§áÂèó‰∫âËÆÆÁöÑÁÇÆÂè∞ÂÖ¨Âõ≠ÂüéÂ∏ÇÂºπÊÄßËÆ°ÂàíÂ∞ÜÂøÉÁà±ÁöÑ‰∏äÂ±ÇÊàøÈó¥ÈõïÂ°ëÂåñ‰∏∫Â∫üÂ¢ü
item.description:
The Upper Room came tumbling down.

A beloved public art project in Battery Park City was demolished Thursday¬†to make way for a new stormproof seawall ‚Äî leaving local park advocates mourning its loss and saying they believed it didn‚Äôt need to get washed away.

‚ÄúThere are a lot of people questioning why the art piece had to be destroyed,‚Äù said John Dellaportas, the Vice President of The Battery Alliance.

‚ÄúHow they connect climate change to destroying a piece of public art on really high ground is beyond me.‚Äù

The 20-columned sculpture called the Upper Room had stood at the Esplanade entrance at Albany Street for nearly 40 years before it was reduced to rubble Thursday.

Crews took jackhammers, saws and backhoes to the Upper Room, destroying in just two days the sculpture that had served as a neighborhood gathering place for nearly 40 years.

It was the first public art piece commissioned by the Battery Park City Authority, which appraised the stunning piece at $1.5 million.

The authority says it had no choice but to destroy the beloved Upper Room as it prepares to break ground on its controversial North/West Battery Park City Resiliency¬†(NWBPCR) project.

Its longtime home sits atop a space the authority is eyeing to construct a large tide gate that would mitigate future flooding in the event of the next Superstorm Sandy.

Plus, the sculpture had shown signs of cracking in recent years and would have been difficult to relocate because the columns are filled with rebar

But one art conservator theorized the BPCA could have saved the neighborhood staple, but was just too cheap to try.

‚ÄúA sculpture like this costs more to move than to destroy, but the BPCA has a responsibility as the stewards of a public collection,‚Äù Melanie Brussat, who was hired by the BPCA six years ago to assess the condition of Upper Room, told Broadsheet.

‚ÄúThe engineering firm that recommended destroying Upper Room is expert at overseeing resiliency projects, but doesn‚Äôt have extensive experience with public art pieces. The BPCA should have hired experts in moving and preserving art.‚Äù

It‚Äôs anguished artist, Ned Smyth, had similar theories, telling The Post he had asked the group to consider relocating the sculpture off BPCA property.

‚ÄúThey didn‚Äôt want to pay, is the bottom line. It‚Äôs all about money, I think, and to rebuild it, I‚Äôd need to recast all the parts of it again and reset them ‚Äî they were set on real foundations,‚Äù Smyth, 77, said.
item.author: Katherine Donlevy
